types.name: Simple Sentence
types.description: One independent clause with a single subject-verb relationship

patterns.example: Students study.
Students study grammar.
Students are diligent.
Students study grammar carefully.
Students study grammar in the library.

types.name: Compound Sentence
types.description: Two or more independent clauses joined by coordination

patterns.example: Students study grammar, and teachers provide guidance.
Students study grammar; teachers provide guidance.
Students study grammar; however, some struggle with application.
patterns.structure: Independent Clause ; Conj. Adv , Independent Clause

types.name: Complex Sentence
types.description: One independent clause with one or more dependent clauses

patterns.example: Students study grammar when they prepare for exams.
Students study grammar because it improves writing.
Students improve if they study grammar regularly.
Students who study grammar improve their writing.
Although students study grammar, mistakes still occur.

types.name: Compound-Complex Sentence
types.description: Multiple independent clauses with at least one dependent clause

patterns.example: When students study grammar, their writing improves, and their confidence grows.
patterns.structure: Dependent Clause + Main Clause + Coordinating Conj + Main Clause

patterns.example: Students study grammar, and teachers provide exercises that reinforce learning.
patterns.structure: Main Clause + Coord. Conj + Main Clause + Relative Clause

types.name: Gerund-Based Sentences
types.description: Sentences using -ing forms as nouns

patterns.example: Studying grammar improves writing skills.
Students enjoy studying grammar.
Students learn by studying grammar regularly.
Understanding complex grammatical structures requires consistent practice.
The teacher appreciated the students' studying grammar diligently.

types.name: Infinitive-Based Sentences
types.description: Sentences using 'to + verb' forms

patterns.example: To study grammar is essential for clear writing.
Students study grammar to improve their writing.
Grammar is difficult to master completely.
Students want to improve their grammatical accuracy.
The exercise was too difficult to complete quickly.
patterns.structure: S + be + too/enough + Adj + to + Verb

types.name: Participial Constructions
types.description: Sentences using participles to add information efficiently

patterns.example: Walking to school, I reviewed my grammar notes.
Written in haste, the essay contained several errors.
Having studied grammar extensively, students write with confidence.
The exam was extremely difficult, causing many students to fail.
patterns.structure: Main Clause , causing/leading to/resulting in + Object

patterns.example: Students studying grammar improve their writing.

types.name: Passive Voice Sentences
types.description: Sentences where the subject receives the action

patterns.example: Grammar is taught in schools worldwide.
Grammar is taught by experienced teachers.
patterns.structure: S + be + Past Participle + by + Agent

patterns.example: Grammar should be studied regularly.
Grammar has been taught for centuries.
Students avoid being tested on complex grammar.

types.name: Conditional Sentences
types.description: Sentences expressing conditions and their results

patterns.example: If you heat water to 100¬∞C, it boils.
If students study grammar, they will improve.
If students studied more, they would improve faster.
If students had studied, they would have passed.
patterns.structure: If + Past Perfect , would have + Past Participle

patterns.example: If students had studied grammar, they would be confident now.
patterns.structure: If + Past Perfect , would + Verb (present result)

types.name: Inversion for Emphasis
types.description: Reversing subject-verb order for rhetorical effect

patterns.example: Never have students been so motivated to learn grammar.
Only by studying regularly can students master grammar.
Had students studied harder, they would have succeeded.
So complex was the grammar that students needed extra help.
patterns.structure: So/Such + Adj/Noun + be + Subject + that Clause

types.name: Cleft Sentences
types.description: Sentences restructured to emphasize specific information

patterns.example: It is grammar that improves writing most effectively.
patterns.structure: It + be + Focused Element + that/who + Clause

patterns.example: What students need is more practice with complex sentences.
All students want is clear explanations.
patterns.structure: All + Subject + V + be + Noun Phrase

types.name: Addition/Extension
types.description: Adding information or extending ideas

patterns.example: Students study grammar, and they practice writing regularly.
Grammar improves clarity; moreover, it enhances credibility.
In addition to studying grammar, students read extensively.
patterns.structure: In addition to + Gerund , Main Clause

types.name: Contrast
types.description: Showing opposition or difference

patterns.example: Students study grammar, but some struggle with application.
Grammar is challenging; however, practice leads to mastery.
While students study grammar, they often neglect vocabulary.
Despite studying grammar, students make persistent errors.
patterns.structure: Despite/In spite of + Gerund/Noun , Main Clause

types.name: Cause/Effect
types.description: Showing reasons and results

patterns.example: Students improve because they study grammar systematically.
Students studied grammar diligently, so their writing improved.
Grammar was taught effectively; as a result, students excelled.
Due to studying grammar, students write more confidently.
patterns.structure: Due to/Owing to + Gerund/Noun , Main Clause

types.name: Concession
types.description: Acknowledging opposing points while maintaining position

patterns.example: Although students study grammar, mistakes still occur.
Even though grammar is challenging, students persist.
While grammar rules help, practice is equally important.

types.name: Condition
types.description: Expressing hypothetical situations

patterns.example: If students study grammar, their writing improves.
Students won't improve unless they practice grammar.
Students will succeed provided they study consistently.

types.name: Purpose
types.description: Expressing intention or goal

patterns.example: Students study grammar to improve their writing.
In order to master grammar, students practice daily.
patterns.structure: In order to + Infinitive , Main Clause

patterns.example: Students study grammar so that they can write clearly.

types.name: Result
types.description: Showing outcomes or consequences

patterns.example: Students studied so hard that they achieved top scores.
patterns.structure: S + V + so + Adj/Adv + that + Result Clause

patterns.example: It was such difficult grammar that students needed help.
patterns.structure: It + be + such + Adj + Noun + that + Result Clause

types.name: Participial Phrases with Adjectives
types.description: Combining adjectives with participial constructions

patterns.example: Unchecked technological expansion may result in unprecedented ethical dilemmas, challenging our very definition of human identity.
patterns.structure: Adjective + Noun + Main Verb + Object , Present Participle Phrase

patterns.example: The government acted decisively, implementing emergency measures aimed at reversing years of environmental neglect.
patterns.structure: S + V + Adverb , Present Participle + Object + Past Participle Modifier

patterns.example: Urban overcrowding has escalated beyond control, producing social tensions that threaten the stability of entire communities.
patterns.structure: S + V + Complement , producing/creating + Noun + Relative Clause

patterns.example: Deeply polarized political debates often deteriorate into hostility, alienating citizens from the democratic process.
patterns.structure: Adverb + Adjective + Noun + V , Present Participle + Object

types.name: Perfect Participles
types.description: Showing completed action before main clause

patterns.example: Having been neglected for decades, rural infrastructure is now collapsing, forcing thousands to migrate towards urban centers.
patterns.structure: Having been + Past Participle + Time , Main Clause , forcing + Object

patterns.example: Having studied grammar extensively, students now write with remarkable clarity and precision.
patterns.structure: Having + Past Participle , S + V + with + Adjective + Noun

types.name: Complex Adjectival Phrases
types.description: Multi-layered modification of nouns

patterns.pattern: Present Participle as Consequence with Adjectives
patterns.example: Immigration policies, frequently perceived as unjust, risk creating mistrust and resentment among minority groups.
patterns.structure: Noun , Adverb + Past Participle + as + Adj , V + Gerund + Objects

patterns.example: Failing to regulate social media responsibly can lead to misinformation spreading uncontrollably within hours.
patterns.structure: Gerund Phrase + can lead to + Noun + Present Participle + Adverb

types.name: Emotional/Evaluative Adjectives
types.description: Adjectives conveying strong judgment or emotion

patterns.example: Desperate and disillusioned, young graduates are turning to foreign opportunities, reshaping the national labor market.
patterns.structure: Adj + and + Adj , S + V , Present Participle + Object

patterns.example: While global trade remains an engine of growth, it also intensifies competition, pressuring local industries to reduce costs at any price.
patterns.structure: While + Clause , S + also + V , Present Participle + Object + to-Infinitive

types.name: Double Participial Expansion
types.description: Two participial phrases modifying the subject

patterns.example: Driven by curiosity and seeking significance, many individuals embrace risky innovations, transforming entire cultural landscapes.
patterns.structure: Past Participle Phrase + and + Present Participle Phrase , S + V + O , transforming + Object
